g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Social influence approaches that communicate what other people do or think can encourage mitigation
, as can social models of desired actions
Abrahamse and Steg 2013; Wolske et al. 2020; Sussman and Gifford 2013)
elative to others can be effective
(Nolan et al. 2008; Allcott 2011; Schultz et al. 2015)
although not always, and effect sizes are small
Interventions that capitalize on people’s motivation to be consistent can promote mitigation actions
. Examples are commitment strategies where people pledge to act
, implementation intentions where they additionally explicate how a
they will perform the relevant action and how they would cope with possible barriers
related strategies that make people aware of inconsistencies
up approaches can promote mitigation action
Haxeltine 2012; Abrahamse and Steg 2013; Sloot et al. 2018)
r among their employees and customers by communicati
(van der Werff et al. 2021; Ruepert et al. 2017)
Default options, where a preset choice is implemented if
do not select another option, can promote
mitigation actions such as energy savings, green electricity uptake, and meat
et al. 2021; Pichert and Katsikopoulos 2008; Ölander and Thøgersen 2014; Kunreuther and Weber
2014; Bessette et al. 2014; Ebeling and Lotz 2015; Liebe et al. 2018; Campbell
ility of policy, mitigation options and system changes
Public acceptability reflects the extent to which the public evaluates climate policy, mitigation options,
Public acceptability of policy and mitigation options is higher when people expect these
have more positive and less negative consequences for self, others, and the environment
2015; Drews and Van den Bergh 2016; Perlaviciute and Steg 2014)
a culturally valued landscape is affected by renewable energy development
. Acceptability can increase after a policy or change has been implemented and the
consequences appear to be more positive tha
; effective policy trials can thus build public support.
Next, climate policy and low carbon options are evaluated as more fair and acceptable when costs and
benefits are distributed equally, and when nature, the environment and future generatio
(Schuitema et al. 2011; Drews and Van den Bergh 2016)
. Compensating affected groups for losses due
to policy or systems changes enhanced public acceptability in some cases
but people may disagree on which compensation would be
, or feel they are being bribed
more acceptable when revenues are earmarked for environmental purposes
Climate policy and mitigation options, such as renewable energy pro
jects, are also perceived as more
fair and acceptable when the public
could participate in the decision making
Wright 2005; Terwel et al. 2012; Perlaviciute and Squintani 2020; Arvai 2003; Walker and
eople are more motivated to participate in decision making on local projects than on
